>>18903665
>Non-American here. Does kosher salt taste any different to.... not kosher salt?
It's miss labeled. Salt isn't kosher or not, it's just salt. What is called kosher salt should more correctly be called koshering salt and was/is used to cure meats into a kosher food.

All the kosher part indicates is that it's suitable for curing a meat because of the size of the chunks. Any recipe that uses kosher salt but otherwise dissolves it is just pretending to be fancy by using a slightly more expensive salt. (no salt is really expensive in the modern world).

Nevertheless, I knew that presentation wasn't everything, so I carried on. I picked up the scrambled mass and, upon bringing it to my mouth, was hit with a pungent aroma that seemed to seat itself in the back of my sinus. Tears welled in my eyes as I opened my mouth and took my first (and only) bite. I tasted nothing upon entry. I tasted nothing upon the first bite of the chew. I chewed thrice more before "flavor" made itself known. It was not a welcome one. I have never had the displeasure of chewing on an old dishrag that had been dropped and forgotten behind a restaurant dishwasher, but this must have been its closest "edible" imitation.
I let the chewed mass fall from my mouth, back into the so-called "wrapper", letting it dribble upon the supposed "sandwich". I went to the nearest drug store and bought mouth wash - it took 5 cycles to rinse out the taste. Unfortunately, the pungent aroma that had seated itself in my sinus would persist for hours.

It was not until I stopped at my local Arby's restaurant and ordered a Roast Beef Sandwich that I had would have a sandwich worthy of the day. And a much-enjoyed one, at that. I highly recommend everyone try Arby's Roast Beef.

Get a gravity one. Get a good brand like Berkel, small diameter blade (size of the blade decides a lot of the cost and it's irrelevant at home). Look at second hand/auction sites and be quick, professional butchers are hawking them 24/7 for good reason, these things last decades.

While I personally prefer cow milk over goat (goat one has a weird taste that doesn't quite sit with me), goat cheese is kino

Supposedly goat milk/cheese is easier to digest if you have any problems with that (small lipid globules). Goat dairy products have more vitA, calcium, potassium, phosphorus and niacin, so technically healthier. It is more caloric, has more protein (on average) but more sodium.

Like I said, I don't recommend goat milk unless you can put up with the taste of grass (at least that's how I'd describe it), but cheese is really good and goes fantastic with a fresh slice of bread and a slice of smoked ham.

I tend to aire on the spicy side when it comes to ramen. What I used to do when I worked down the road from the Korean store:
>go into store with $20
>buy $20 worth of individual packs of ramen I had not tried before
>try all of them
>decide what I liked from that bunch and took pictures of the package (because lol some of them don't have any engrish text)
>return to store the next time
>repeat process
Some recommendations:
>paldo namja (kicks the shit out of Shin Black imo)
>paldo teumsae
>paldo jjajangmen
>any samyang buldak varieties
>I prefer the cheese kind
>did not like the carbonara or curry
>ottogi sesame with the egg block
>regular shin is fine if you're planning on adding stuff to it or experimenting with the "ramen hacks" that pop up all the time

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18878544
>Any recommendations from /ck/?
make your own
a bulk pack of dried ramen and a can of vegeta only takes 5 minutes + however long it takes to get the water boiling (and costs far less per serve than packets of instant), and you can improve it from there by making stock yourself, using fresh meat or vegetables, a splash of soy sauce or hoisin or some other sauce, aroma oils etc.
It's also less wasteful since you aren't throwing away massive amounts of plastic wrapping, foil sauce packets.
Once you start making your own you'll quickly realise how oily and artificial the instant ramens are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18902536
I make a lot of deviled eggs
Like, the egg prices are hurting me
There are only two things that ensure you can peel the egg easily
That you steam them, and you shock them in ice water immediately
When you steam an egg you might want to poke a hole in the air pocket with a safety needle or thumbtack
Rotate the needle, don't push it straight in
Everything else is luck of the draw
I've tried old eggs, dried eggs, warm eggs, cold eggs, none of those matter

One thing to make sure they come out pretty and uniform is to get grade AA
They will also center better if you cook them top end up the top end is the round end with the air pocket
They make egg steamer baskets that are useful when you need to make a ton of eggs

>australian answer
I grew up on an olive farm, so I grab another 2L cask from family whenever I run low

On the rare occasion I need to buy some I'll get cobrams estate or red island as good quality at their price point.

The easymode rules:
>but actual olive oil (looking at you america)
>buy as local as reasonable, anything imported will usually be older
>buy as close to the harvest/crushing date as possible. The 'best before' date is fine to compare across brands.
Age is key for flavour. If you want some sharp grassy flavours, get an early press as young as possible. If all you want is cooking oil, 2 years old is fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18902782
You can cook with it, it's just that because it's unrefined, its smoke point can vary a lot from one blend to the next. Furthermore, if it's low quality or has been adulterated with other oils (as is frequently the case with the product found on American supermarket shelves), the smoke point tends to fall even lower.

Also, some culinary traditions shy away from olive oil because of its assertive flavor. Classical French cuisine, for instance, tends to prefer butter for cooking, and more neutral oils such as grapeseed are traditional even for mayonnaise; olive oil is more associated with Provençal dishes. Likewise, olive oil would be completely out of place in Asian food.

>>18903747
The best thing for deep frying is beef tallow, but you'll probably have to find a market that sells suet and render it yourself. Lard (if you can get the non-hydrogenated stuff) is good, too, but has a lower smoke point than tallow. Avocado oil is close in composition to olive oil (high monounsaturated, low polyunsaturated), and has a much higher smoke point than even the best extra virgin. Peanut oil is a cheaper option that's much better than shit like soy or canola (it's also probably the best choice among the traditional options for Asian dishes, at least in the West where rice bran oil is harder to find and generally pricey).

A cheap porcelain gaiwan is all you really need. Yixing maybe makes a slight difference but it is not work worrying about when starting out.

>If i keep the boxes I have closed and outside of light they should last a long time right?
Those teas should be fine indefinitely if they came sealed up well. You could stick the boxes in a ziplock bags for additional protection if you want. How did the tea come stored in the boxes?

>>18900733
>Is an electric kettle with a temperature setting where it can keep the water at a certain temp necessary?
For puerh boiling or just off boiling water is what is typically used. An electric kettle that you can set to lower temperatures is nice for green tea and being able to keep the water hot is convenient but you don't need one starting out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18889540
Darker roasts will offgas very quickly, but the exposed surface oils will oxidize and go rancid just as quickly. Thats the skunky stale smell you get from grocery store bags. Spoiled plant fat doesn't taste good, drink those within a month off roasting. Anything lighter than that will be fine a good while longer if you're not constantly getting in the bag exposing it to fresh oxygen. Thats where shit like airscape containers(anything sealed with a one way valve really) come in handy. You're not letting fresh oxygen react with the roasted plant fats inside your beans, while letting them vent carbon dioxide. co2 doesn't taste good. Thats why you stir crema on espresso into the shot. Its a sour bitter layer of trapped gasses preventing you from getting to the actual flavors you're trying to extract. Resting will depend on the roast and density of the bean. There's no harm in testing how they taste once a week, just avoid constant exposure to fresh oxygen. Also why people like the meme single dosing tubes.
https://www.wired.com/2009/10/your-tongue-the-carbon-dioxide-sensor/

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18889137
Buy what you can drink within 2-4 weeks. By the time roasted coffee gets to you it has rested enough. Coffee is rested for 1-3 days after roasting for the flavors to develop. Do not confuse this with the spergy weeks-long CO2 off-gassing espresso dorks do. They do this so that they can more precisely dial in their shots at the expense of losing flavor. I repeat: they are losing flavor as a trade off for replicability of espresso shot extraction. The volatile aromatic compounds that give good, fresh coffee its taste are lost over time. It is very noticeable after about 2-4 weeks.

The other anons had some good reccs but probably the best budget settup would be a Breville Bambino(along with an unpressurized portafilter and a decent tamper) and a Kingrinder K4.

Assuming you pay full price for all of it, and you already have a decent kitchen scale, you're looking at around 500 dollar investment for what people here would consider a extremely budget settup but non-autists would consider the best coffee they ever tasted. It'll get you at least 75% of the way to the perfect shot.

If you're in the US, bed bath and beyond tends to have discounts on the Bambino, in store only.

There's no best recipe. I like this one from Sally's Baking Addiction:
https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/my-favorite-carrot-cake-recipe/

I recommend making it according to the recipe, though you can substitute the oil for browned butter if you want, that turned out tasty when I tried it. Add raisins/chopped dates to the mix for some different texture if he doesn't dislike them, and use enough chopped pecans to cover all the frosting.

Note the size of the recipe. You can shrink it down to a single egg to make a mini batch in a muffin tin and adjust things according to your taste after.

>>18877773
I came up with the idea for Peat Monster, nice to see it mentioned here. The first batch was a 50/50 blend of Caol Ila and Clynelish (or maybe Ardmore, it was a long time ago lol), both about 10 or 15 years old, aged in ex-bourbon, and bottled at cask strength. It was just called Monster. John Glaser, the founder, didn’t want to make it at first because he didn’t personally enjoy peaty whisky. It turned out to be the blend that put him on the map, so he decided to make it regular production item as Peat Monster, with some water added to lower the proof.

you've gone about it wrong from the start if you thought cheap flavored whiskey would be easier to drink or be free of the quality's of ethanol and how it affects your body.

first learn how to drink(approach it like a hot beverage or soup, less is more, savor it for as long as you can muster and do not do shots). then find what you like to drink(better to have 2 or more bottles poured at once to compare and find your sweetspot). then you combine those aspects and become all that is man(who can appreciate the glass in his hand as well as the drink within).

if you're only looking for inebriation then go down the buttchug path.

>>18900784
Not possible to "farm" shark. Salmon and freshwater fish lay eggs in shallow areas in rivers and don't need to move much in early life stages. So it's easy to "farm" these fish (just block off part of a river and hatch them). But sharks swim around the whole ocean and "birth" motile young that immediately need a ton of room. So the shark lives its normal life while gestating its young, and the young also immediately starts swimming at birth. Nobody can block off a huge part of the ocean to make this a controlled process like they can with salmon farms.

I bought one of those kits like 10 years ago off Woot for maybe $20. I wasn't expecting much from the beer, and got what I expected, but I was already doing a couple 5 gallon carboys, and getting a gallon jug with the other equipment was a nice addition to experiment with. If you're serious about trying out homebrewing just buy a real set. It's like $100 for all the basic equipment with a basic ingredient set included. You're probably not going to make the best beer right off the bat, but a 5 gallon recipe is going to get you close to 50 bottles, which is $2 a bottle for beer you brewed yourself, and you get to keep all the equipment, which will make subsequent batches less than half the price.

If you want a good cuisine for vegetables and vegetarian food in general, nothing beats Indian food. And I'm not talking about the stereotypical Indian restaurant food, but the home cooked food that Indians eat everyday.
Most of it involves stir frying vegetables with some diced onions, minced ginger and garlic, cumin seeds, ground cumin, ground coriander, and maybe some garam masala. That's it. And all of those spices are added just enough to give the vegetables some flavor, not heart burn inducing amounts like what restaurants do.

I cook squash, zucchini, onions, and mushrooms in the same pan I just cooked meat in. I deglaze the pan with some wine, cognac, or stock after the veggies get a little caramelization, and I use herbs that compliment veggies well such as tarragon.

>>18902713
The best way is, after roasting them in the oven or sauteing them in a pan with oil, cover them in a sauce.

Bechamel sauce, or some savory sauce based on some kind of meat (or meat-flavored) broth thickened with starch slurry or roux, and add any herbs, seasonings, and spices you want. paprika, soy sauce, fish sauce, cinnamon, anything you like.

It's important that you cook the vegetables through first. Many vegetables don't taste good raw but become utterly delicious if cooked through until soft and tender throughout.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18904320
I forgot to mention that somehow, some vegetables don't lose their undesirable flavors from just boiling or simmering in liquid, so I wouldn't toss vegetables in water or broth to cook them. Only put them in a sauce or liquid after they've been cooked.
Steaming is another great cooking method for vegetables. And my rule is I do not consume vegetables until they're totally tender and soft throughout.

>>18903304
Should be pointed out that the cost of parboiled white rice(the cheapest rice available in Canada/USA) versus white flour is roughly equivalent at the calorie/dollar. It's perfectly fine to bake or pan-fry some bread instead of rice for a meal and will help you not go insane without costing you any more money.

Something like Focaccia made with canola oil will be nice and calorie dense for very little money. Or to keep on the bean track, you could very easily do a refried bean mixture and use it to fill a bun, providing a ready-made meal of similar cost, calorie, and macro ratio to rice and beans, but also one that you can just grab on the go.

>>18888686
Somalis eat a banana with literally every dish. It's weird, but primitive countries generally don't have a rigid distinction between sweet and savoury dishes the way they do. In some regions of Uganda, boiled bananas are their staple carb, they eat dishes such as boiled bananas with beans.

Another weird thing done with spaghetti in Africa is the Ethiopian way of eating it. They eat spaghetti in tomato sauce but the whole thing is served on an injera (very thin pancake made of teff wheat, with a sour taste because the dough is left to ferment for a few days). See pic related for an example.

>adding tomato to ceviche makes it mexican
The Mexican ceviche is not simply a tomato on top of the "original" recipe though. Not only is the tomato incorporated into the dish, other ingredients are also substituted from the south American variant due to differing availability. For example, in Peru (claims to have invented it), they also add hot peppers that Mexicans did not traditionally have access to.
>adding cream to carbonara makes it british/american
It's still Italian with cream. Yes, Italians did make it with cream themselves (albeit less commonly) despite what LARPing purists would have you believe, there are published Italian recipe books that instruct adding cream.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18901521
I’m a professional brewer. It’s worth it if you want to give it as gifts or brew exactly what you enjoy. If you just want to get drunk for dirt cheap then get a food safe 5 gallon bucket, 10 pounds of sugar, some acidic fruit like lemons or pineapple, and actual brewing yeast. For the love of god do not use bread yeast. The real shit is 50 cents for a packet. Also do not use tap water. There are normally chlorine derived chemicals in there that will make your beer taste like plastic ass. Mix everything together until the sugar dissolves, toss the yeast in at 65 degrees f, put plastic wrap over the top. Watch the thing bubble for the next week or so and when they die down, the yeast are done working. The most expensive part of this is figuring out what to bottle it in but if you plan on drinking it quick then 2 liter soda bottles work. I recommend getting into it but start simple. Play with the fruit. Learn how to not brew hang over juice. It can be pretty damn cool.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Makes thirty 750ml bottles for about $20 - $30.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Its something you do because its a fun hobby. Its not really worth doing it to save money unless you're brewing some type of beer thats expensive/hard to find (like a very specific type of fruit/berry sour if thats your thing). Not very expensive to get started either.

>>18898300
These look better…did you melt cheese? By salamder I mean essentially a broiler, where there is a heat source that is on top of food. Place cheese on buns, place under heat for 30 seconds, wala. By flattop I mean a flat metal cooktop with heat underneath that provides a large and consistently heated cook area. Place buns, inside facing up, on flattop or pan, put cheese on and cover, wait one minute and wala. Alternatively you can absolutely put cheese directly on a well seasoned and lightly oiled pan, then put the bread on top that. Use a fish spatula to get it off the cook top…griddled cheese is amazing. Wala

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I grew up in Seattle before Luger sound was a complete sewage dump so sea food is a big part of the dead things I eat. First is freshness. Stop eating frozen fish unless you fry it. It’s always shittier and lacks flavor. Then we get into what species of fish which has to do with fat content, bottom feeder or not, density, and of course flavor. For example, Salmon, if you can find something wild caught without dyes and isn’t actually trout, all you need to do is salt the skin side. Fry it with a layer of butter on the pan on a searing heat then lower the temp and flip it. Put a lid on to bake it until there is just barely a wiggle to the meat then serve it skin side up. Fry onions and potatoes in the fat on searing heat while the meat rests. The flavor of the fish is important. I grew up eating anything with gills. Eel, squid, carp, catfish, cod, crabs, clam. It’s late where I am but I’m happy to share what I can if anyone is interested.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18893872

Yucatecan is my favorite Mexican regional cuisine. It's alot of citrus, habanero, interesting colors, balancing between bright citrus and spicy with earthy annatto and deep black charred produce, seafood, and the infamous cocinita pibil. Some yucatecan deep cuts are sikil pak (it's like a roasted habanero pumpkin seed salsa with the consistency of hummus), xni pec (pink fruity habanero salsa), Recado negro (black habanero salsa made out of burned chiles and tortillas), panuchos/salbutes (puffy tostada/tacos stuffed with beans), and huaraches (Mexican flat breads)

>>18897509
>spaniards introduce spirits in America. Are even less know fact is that the exact process of distilling tequila/mezcal came from filipinos.
>https://www.sapiens.org/culture/tequila-origins-tuba/
None of that is what is said in your source link. Here is the exact paragraph quote:
>They brought coconuts, along with techniques to ferment coconut sap into tuba—an alcoholic beverage consumed in the Philippines since precolonial times, and sometimes distilled into a stronger coconut liquor known as lambanog or bahalina. These fermentation and distillation techniques were applied to agave—a plant native to Mexico and other parts of the Americas—eventually becoming what we now know as tequila (from blue agave) and mezcal (from other agave varieties).
Thus this particular researcher is saying that the distillation process was introduced based on a precolonial process in the Philippines. So "Spaniards introduce spirits in America" is blatantly false in every way (for every definition of "spirits").

In terms of history, tequila by any measure is one of the oldest distilled spirits consumed in mass today, with genever being older. Alcohol is ancient, but consistently drinkable distilled spirits are relatively much more recent.

>>18883946
Basic curry. You just fry some onions and garlic in butter, add curry powder and let it combine and cook for a bit, add milk. Then finish cooking seared chicken in it (thighs work great). >jaggery is just sugar, black salt is just salt, hing tastes like shallots/onions
Wrong on every fucking count. Jaggery is sugar in the same sense that brown sugar is the same as white sugar. Black salt is mostly salt, but has a much different taste due to the other stuff in it and is not a good salt substitute. The flavor of hing is vaguely onion like, but the texture sure isn't like an onion's. You might as well say minced garlic and onion powder are the same.

While most of the things I listed are in garam masala, you're not going to be able to temper right without whole spices, and for that you're going to want things like whole cloves, whole cumin seeds, cinnamon, etc.

In conclusion, deal with it!

>>18885123
The sauce that makes up the curry is usually a very thick pureed vegetable stock made from onions, garlic, carrots, tomato and bell peppers that spices are then added to. The meat or veg of the dish is usually fried in ghee with a garlic & ginger puree, has about a tablespoon of whatever spice mixture is required for the dish and then 1/4 cup of condensed tomato paste and a couple of ladles of that vegetable stock are added in until they get the right consistency/colour. There's a lot more veg in an Indian curry than almost any other kind of takeaway.

This. Most of the takeaways only provide a bread-type item and a meat dish. >>18880509
If you ever get the chance to go to a place with pakistani restaurants then eat dishes that pakistanis specifically specialize in. Feel like people get disappointed with paki food because they're expecting indian food and order stereotypical stuff like butter chicken when those stuff aren't really popular with pakistanis and so we naturally suck at making them.

We really specialize in the meat dishes like nihari, pulao, keema, karahi, all the different types of bbq like tikkas, chargha, and kabobs (seekh, chapli, shami, bun, etc.). Pakis in general do bbq way better than indians and as a texan you'll probably love it. Also try the naans because we're better at that too. We have more variety but try sesame naan instead of garlic naan. If they don't have sesame naan on the menu ask them to put sesames on it. It's a million times better than the garlic naans that indians eat and tastes really good with bbq

>>18883946
aloo bhujia, karahi, and keema are all extremely easy since they're all cooked the same way. For all 3 dishes you just fry onions, tomatoes, and ginger garlic paste till you have a sauce. Put seasoning. I only use like 6 which is salt, red chilli powder, turmeric, coriander powder, cumin powder, and garam masala. You can adjust the seasoning however you want. Once you have you've seasoned, you can either put chopped up potatoes and that makes aloo bhujia or you can put a meat like chicken, lamb, or whatever and that makes karahi. If you use minced meat instead that makes keema. At the end just add cilantro and jalepeno to whatever dish you decided to make. It's so easy and these were the first dishes I've ever learned to cook because you literally can't mess up

>>18897372
Nice, post recibe please.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18899006
5 taters
2 cups sour cream
3/4 stick of butter
6 green onions
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp pepper
garlic powder to taste
8g of cheese (i used a Mexican cheese blend, some mozzarella, and a little asiago and parmesan)
boil potatoes till they're partway cooked, then shred them once they're cooled.
melt the butter and add in chopped green onions, salt, and pepper, then cook a lil bit and put in a bowl with the sour cream. add the garlic powder and mix around till they're all incorporated well, then mix in your cheese. butter a casserole dish and put in the potatoes and the cheese mix, make sure to mix everything together well. put in your oven (you should preheat it) at 350°F and bake it for 45 minutes to an hour.

>>18901303
It's a really good question and the answer is disappointing: your taste buds work differently in different situations. Stress, holidays, altitude, having to pay, eating together with your partner, memories from childhood, food & drink pairings etc etc all drastically change the way you perceive taste/aroma.

I once got a sangria recipe from a colleague in Barcelona which was phenomenal. We had 50-70m queues all day. When I got back home and tried it in my restaurant it was ok at best. The opposite can (rarely) happen too: you can buy crates of mediocre wine when you taste them which turn out to be gems when you get home.

Instead of learning synonyms for fucking I'd advise you to read Marcel Proust instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yes, you can make butter from heavy cream by whipping or churning it until the fat separates from the liquid. The solid fat that forms is then collected and shaped into butter.

Heavy cream can also be made from whole milk and butter. This is done by heating the whole milk and then adding melted butter to it to increase its fat content. The resulting mixture is then cooled until it reaches the desired consistency.

>>18903570
I came across this dilemma when I first started learning how to cook and wanted to make ingredients myself. My eventual conclusion is that cow "milk" is the milk we drink plus cream, both of which are sold separately, although I'm 100% sure the heavy cream from a grocery store goes through a lot of processing before it gets there, so you may as well buy land-o-lakes butter if you use that. Maybe raw milk from a local farmer still has cream you can separate out? If not, the only solution is to get your own cow and milk it.
It's really weird how every resource on the internet creates this chicken-and-egg problem, but none of them even acknowledge it, much less try to explain it/solve it.

posts.com:
There are two dimensions to alcohol tolerance. One is physiological, one psychological. If you have 80 IQ, you probably have very low psych tolerance. It wont take you much to start acting drunk. If you are 100 lbs soaking wet, or have half a liver, you have no physical tolerance. It wont take much to get you drunk. Now, obviously people can have one problem or the other. For me, im physically very lightweight, but have extraordinary mental tolerance. You need to evaluate your weakness and accomodate. Gain wieght, or start paying attention to your health. You cant magically increase your IQ or "g" to make yourself more resilient, but some mental training might help. Not really a job for /ck/, try /fit/ or /x/ really. Have fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
alcoholic here, the secret is chronic exposure. your liver can only metabolize so many grams of alcohol per hour, so if you drink enough at night you can keep your blood alcohol content at a healthy level throughout the day. i drink half to a whole bottle of whiskey every night and so there are probably only a few hours in a day where i can pass a breathalyzer, usually the last few hours at work before going home to start drinking again. i can tell because that's when the shakes set in. my brain literally can't tolerate not being drunk.
you can get to my level pretty easily by drinking every day and slowly increasing the amount over the space of a few months. trying to be a weekend warrior won't really get you the results you are after, you need to get into a routine and stick with it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Been working at a place off and on for the last 4 years(covid and having a serious medical issue made it so it was more like 2 ACTUAL years of regular shifts).
Notice my raises were all but erased because of a minimum wage going up(Started off with the manager saying all line cooks start at $2 over minimum wage, and get raises every 9-12 months based on performance. Because of covid i never got the last 2 evaluations). Since then minimum wage has gone up by $1.85 cents.
New hires are actually paid more than me, even though i literally had to show one how to use a fucking thermometer last time i worked with him.
Tip-outs was also really exaggerated, with the manager saying it averages around $2/hr for BoH. At best, i did maybe $2.20/hr, but prob 80% of the time its around $1/hr.

Pretty fucking demoralized desu. I'm thinking of just handing in my notice tomorrow. I'm also given shitty shifts(like both opening shifts on the weekend. Something that i guess only a few other guys are trained to do.) that are impossible to offload and would cripple the business if i did a no-show.
I'll admit i'm probably one of the weaker cooks there if you only look at the people who are actually fully trained, but i'v never missed a day or came in late, never take breaks(so many other guys just fuck-off for smoke breaks or disappear in the bathroom for 20 minutes. I made it a point to not use the bathroom unless i literally need to) and have stayed past the end of my shift if asked.
I know its a shitty industry to work in, and i have said so myself plenty of times, but when i actually took a moment to reflect on it when i got my tax papers for it, it really hit me just how exploited i feel from working there.

At my place, we'd make i think 18L every 3 or 4 days, and keep it in a big cambro in the cooler. At the start of the day we'd heat up enough to fill a 1/3rd tray and keep it in a steamwell, and add to it if needed.

I also worked at a place that would portion it out in 10oz bags, and re-heat(in the microwave) to order. Steam well works better since its uniformly warm and for some stuff you need to put it in a pipping bag anyway, so having it portioned in a plastic bag is just wasteful and extra hassle.

Never worked as a line cook, but I did briefly work at a factory that made frozen tv dinners and hot meals for Meals on Wheels, and cafeterias too. I mean it was like some dude would just walk past me and say 8 grapes for 37 and place a basket of freshly washed grapes in front of me and expect me to scoop out exactly 296 grapes in less than 30 seconds. There was other shit too like placing scoops of PERFECTLY measured rice into trays that were moving on a conveyer belt at the speed of light, and about 30 minutes into that the rice scooper felt like it weighed 500 lbs.....and there were motherfuckers doing that shit for like 12 hours straight. I never looked at a tv dinner the same way after that job.

Last place I worked 2 best dishes were probably a seafood/cream sauce pasta and lamb chops

>Pasta
>garlic and olive oil into pan with 6 shrimp and 3 scallops, as well as 6 cherry tomatoes, season, add butter
>get the scallops browned on both sides and almost fully cooked and remove from pan, remove shrimp as well
>deglaze pan with white wine, add 12 mussels and heavy cream, season and let reduce to a thick sauce, add back the reserved seafood, add linguine, plate the noodles than add the seafood and mussels to the top, add parsley and parmesan

>Lamb Chops
>pre-marinated
>add to grill and get them marked nicely and cooked to whatever temperature (med rare, etc)
>remove and plate on lemon potatoes and whatever veg we're doing that day

Both were good to eat. The pasta dish was a pain to do 4 or 5 or 6 at a time.

>>18900026
Part of the problem is the legal liabilities. If someone eats food that a restaurant was discarding and gets sick, the restaurant is open to a lawsuit, especially if the owner was willingly giving that food away and not just trashing it. Not only that, but it also encourages the workers to "accidentally" waste food so that there's more left over at the end of the shift.

Of course, there are always exceptions and ways to work around the law, but it's a lot easier to avoid the legal headache and just say "No free food, no exceptions," even if it is wasteful.

posts.com:
kraft dinner casserole.

1 box kraft macaroni and cheese
1/2 of a package mini smoked sausages
about a quarter to 3rd of a bag of frozen mixed vegetables
1/4 cup milk
1/4 cup butter
salt

boil water. salt up the water, the normal amount for making pasta. when it comes to a boil throw in the frozen veggies. cut the little smokies in half. when the water returns to boiling (the frozen veggies will cool it a bit) throw in the macaroni from the mac and cheese and the sausages. cook the amount of time it says on the box. then drain everything, take pot off heat, after draining toss back in the pot and mix in the milk, cheese sauce powder, and butter. stir vigorously and then let sit 5 minutes. serve.

>>18893400
All of these people are out of their minds. Make a stew the day before. Make sure it tastes great, and it will be better the second day.

Also the day before, make smashed potatoes with a shit ton of butter and herbs. You literally just take small potatoes, a bit bigger than a golf ball, boil them until you can smash them in a kitchen towel. Melt half a stick of butter with salt and herbs in a cast iron pan, stack the potatoes in, then do the same melted butter, salt, pepper, herbs on top. Bake until slightly al dente, make sure it tastes great, wrap in foil, refrigerate.

Then just grab basic salad ingredients and wine. The next day when you get there, all you do is pop the oven on to 350, put the stew and potatoes in, find plates, pop open the wine, then banter while slicing tomatoes, maybe crumbling some cheese then tossing in a drizz of balsamic (that you brought) hopefully with a bit of her salt and oil if it's not rancid.

This is how to do it. Take all variables out of the equation. You already know the main stuff is good. All you have to do is put together a salad, drink wine, then plate it all up. This way you can use all of your mental energy trying to appear like you're not autistic.

>>18898079
IMO, it's one of the few 'prepper' type things that's actually worth it, but only if you breed your own chicks and have a sufficiently large breeding program in place. You need a minimum of 30 chickens, split into three flocks (1 rooster per flock, 9 hens). This is called 'spiral breeding'. You could probably get by with less, but flocks of 30 have gone on for hundreds of years with no issues arising from inbreeding.

Then, if SHTF, you can sell chicks and be a king. Like me, right now, during this egg crisis. If you're dependent on others for sourcing chicks, you're not as independent and robust against price hikes. But getting started with a small flock for learning is a great idea. And if you only have room for 10 chickens, maybe you can find a couple local friends or chicken raisers who want to take part in the spiral breeding program and house the remaining 10-20.

I'd recommend a good dual purpose bird like a beilefelder, bresse, etc, since you'll be culling and eating your subpar roos under this program.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18900429
>>18898166
It's not just about yolk color. You can see some of the difference clearly in OP's pic. A major factor in egg quality is the firmness vs wateriness of the yolk, inner and outer whites, and the relative size and separation of the latter two. That's why even all the most basic caged industrial eggs are divided into grades A, B, and C based on that, of which only grade A are sold direct to consumer in grocery stores, while B and C (still perfectly edible) are used commercially in baked or processed goods.

The stereotypical good-environment good-diet eggs will typically those qualities that define grade A, but be even more pronounced.

went to a funeral with my then girlfriend in japan
her grandma was apparently some famous person, family had 2 katanas from the emperor, many medals and such for the family's research in botany

>very cold, soggy

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Where is the line you draw when it comes to buying certain ingredients vs preparing/growing other ingredients from home?
How many of you truly prefer strictly home made fresh ingredients or do you make some exceptions and say fuck it and buy bulk/pre packaged ingredients from the store?
If you're okay with the latter, do you make exceptions for imported/higher quality costly ingredients or just buy whatever's most convenient in the moment?
I'm kinda new to cooking since it's something I've been trying when I started dieting a few months back and I'll be honest and say I usually take the convenience over having to prepare certain ingredients, although I'm interested in possibly making my own burger buns once I start making my own smash burgers, but outside of just trying it once to see how comfortable I am with it, I imagine it'll be a one off experiment that may turn out well enough but maybe I won't personally engage in every time I make burgers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There's no hard defined "line" as much as knowing what your weaknesses are when it comes to cooking things yourself, or what's just not suitable for you in your situation at home like not having special equipment or enough workspace, time, ect.

For example, bread made by someone else is always better than the bread I can make myself at home because I'm just not that good at baking bread. I still bake bread myself sometimes for fun and to improve, but more often than not if I want a decent loaf of bread I'll just buy one and I'm okay with that, and I know where to get really fucking good bread.

This thinking can be applied to nearly all ingredients and cooking. If you know your limitations and shortcomings, there's no problem with just buying what is available to you conveniently and quickly.

You can still make attempts at improve your cooking skills in the meantime of course, getting better at making certain things slowly but surely. Practice makes better.

If you want to learn how to cook, filmmaker Robert Rodriguez gave really good advice: think of your five most favorite foods, and just learn how to cook those five things, and learn how to cook them really well. Eventually you'll get the hang of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18900084
Depends on the cost/value ratio. Is that green craft Parmigiano worth saving $3 over buying a hunk of the real thing? No. Is it worth it to spend an entire day making stock from scratch when you can buy some store bought stock and fortify it in a fraction of the time to be just as good as fully home made? No. Is it worth the effort to save $2-3 by making your basic sandwich bread at home? Maybe. I'm still crunching the numbers on bread makers to see what the economics of bread making really are. If you're making basic sandwich bread by hand there is no way its cheaper at home simply because of the time you need to invest. If you can huck all your ingredients into a bread maker and walk away, the math gets interesting and starts to get down to how much the bread maker costs and how cheaply you can buy ingredients. Pasta is absolutely more economical to buy from the store because of the time needed to make it at home and the mess you create. Unless you're eating pasta every single day it's cheaper to find a local shop that will sell you fresh pasta.
